projectDesc.p: To the tune “Fortune Teller”—"The Waning Moon"is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Fortune Teller”—"The Waning Moon"
The waning moon hangs on the thinning sycamore tree.
The dripping clock stops; all men become quiet.
Sometimes I would see an isolated man come and go on his own
Like the distant and vague silhouette of a lone wild goose.
Startled, it flies up and turns its head;
It has resentment in its heart yet no one notices.
Picking among all the cold branches, but not resting on any,
It is alone and abandoned on the freezing isle of sand.
